content.description:
Grateful is a contender for best slab climb in Colorado. Start on massive, cobbled shelf in the corridor, and move left hand to the perfect pocket. Walk your feet up, and make a long lock off to a small, shallow, mono crimp. Walk your feet up, and make a very tension-y move to an even worse, shallow, left hand mono. Build your feet, and do a desperate stab to a left hand crimp. Match, and walk your feet up for a committing move to a huge jug at the lip.

Video beta:

https://youtu.be/JimCowcvnxY

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8x0Pg1HKg3Y
content.location: From the obvious trail below the Corona Crag, take another well worn trail southeast across the stream. Walk about 50 feet, and, before the first cave, you will see the corridor and striking wall on your right.

content.description: The crux it traversing right until you reach the arete, and layback all the way to the top.

A dyno! Start on the far right side of the huge, man made cave matched on a smiley face like crimp. Put your feet on the huge, chossy ledge, and jump all points off to the lip. Top out. The movement is amazing.

Video beta:

https://youtu.be/r9lKxoPsTZ4

.
content.location: On the far right side of the huge, man made cave, itâ€™s the first line you come to, and you literally put your pads on the trail.

content.description: The "crux" is at the top but is not real difficult. It is however 15 feet off the ground.
content.location: The rock faces south. A lot of beer cans and stuff was left behind by high school kids.

pathTokens: Denver Metropolitan Area Bouldering and Buildering
